iii. The sentence is negative and the stateful verb is negated with [لَا]{.ar} or [مَا]{.ar}.
     We again assume here that the sentence [HAl]{.trn2} contains a pronoun that refers to the person of ḥāl.
     In this case,
     the [و]{.ar}\ of [HAl]{.trn2}
     is prohibited.

     (@) [وَمَا لَنَا لَا نُؤْمِنُ بِٱللَّهِ]{.ar}
         [[[سورة المائدة]{.ar} 5:84](https://quran.com/5/84) cited by [النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 2/59 and [أوضح المسالك لابن هشام]{.ar} 2/289]{.citex}  
         "And why should we not believe in Allāh"

     (@) [عَهَدْتُكَ مَا تَصْبُو وَفِيكَ شَبِيبَةٌ]{.ar}
         [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 2/60 and [أوضح المسالك لابن هشام]{.ar} 2/290]{.citex}  
         "I knew you when you were not childish while [you had] in you youth."  
         ([مَا تَصْبُوا]{.ar} "You were not childish" is a sentence [HAl]{.trn2})

 iv. The sentence is negative and the stateful verb is negated with [لَمْ]{.ar}.
     Here, the sentence [HAl]{.trn2} need not contain a pronoun that refers to the person of ḥāl.
     In this case,
     the [و]{.ar}\ of [HAl]{.trn2}
     is usually kept,
     although it is permissible to drop it.
     For example:

     (@) [أَوْ قَالَ أُوحِىَ إِلَىَّ وَلَمْ يُوحَ إِلَيْهِ شَىْءٌ]{.ar}
         [[[سورة الأنعام]{.ar} 6:93](https://quran.com/6/93) cited by [النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 2/60]{.citex}  
         "or says, 'It has been inspired to me,' while nothing has been inspired to him"

     (@) [فَٱنْقَلَبُوا بِنِعْمَةٍ مِنَ ٱللَّهِ وَفَضْلٍ لَمْ يَمْسَسْهُمْ سُوءٌ]{.ar}
         [[[سورة الأنعام]{.ar} 6:93](https://quran.com/6/93) cited by [النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 2/60]{.citex}  
         "So they returned with favor from Allāh and bounty, no harm having touched them."

     (@) [أَقْبَلَ مُحَمَّدٌ وَلَمْ يَحْمِلْ كُتُبَهُ]{.ar}
         [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 2/60]{.citex}  
         [أَقْبَلَ سَعِيدٌ لَمْ يَحْمِلْ كُتُبَهُ]{.ar}
         [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 2/60]{.citex}  
         "[#muHammad]{.trn2}/[#saeId]{.trn2} approached while he didn't carry his books."

     If the sentence [HAl]{.trn2} does not have a pronoun that links to the person of ḥāl then
     the [و]{.ar}\ of [HAl]{.trn2}
     is to be used.
     For example:

     (@) [أَقْبَلَ سَعِيدٌ وَلَمْ تَطْلُعِ ٱلشَّمْسُ]{.ar}
         [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 2/60]{.citex}  
         "[#saeId]{.trn2} approached while the sun had not risen."

     (@) [وَلَقَدْ خَشِيتُ بِأَنْ أَمُوتَ وَلَمْ تَدُرْ لِلْحَرْبِ دَائِرَةٌ عَلَى ابْنَيْ ضَمْضَمِ]{.ar}
         [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 2/60]{.citex}  
         "And indeed I feared that I would die, while a turn [of misfortune] had not [yet] turned, in battle, on the two sons of [#DamDam]{.trn2}"  
         ([وَلَمْ تَدُرْ لِلْحَرْبِ دَائِرَةٌ]{.ar} is the sentence [HAl]{.trn2})


  v. The sentence is negative and the stateful verb is negated with [لَمَّا]{.ar}.
     Here again, the sentence [HAl]{.trn2} need not contain a pronoun that refers to the person of ḥāl.
     In this case,
     the [و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2}
     is typically chosen to be used.^[From [[إعراب القرآن للدرويش]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/iraab-aldarweesh/7/4) for [سورة الأعراف]{.ar} 7:4: [وإن كانت منفية ب «لما» فالمختار ربطها بالواو]{.ar}]
     For example:

     (@) [أَمْ حَسِبْتُمْ أَن تَدْخُلُوا ٱلْجَنَّةَ وَلَمَّا يَعْلَمِ ٱللَّهُ ٱلَّذِينَ جَاهَدُوا مِنكُمْ وَيَعْلَمَ ٱلصَّابِرِينَ]{.ar}
         [[[سورة آل عمران]{.ar} 3:142](https://quran.com/3/142)]{.citex}  
         "Or do you think that you will enter Paradise while Allāh has not yet made evident those of you who fight in His cause and made evident those who are steadfast?"

### The sentence [HAl]{.trn2} strengthens the meaning of the preceding sentence as a whole

Sometimes the [HAl]{.trn2} describes, not just a single word as the person of ḥāl but the preceding sentence as a whole.
(See section\ (ref)).
If the [HAl]{.trn2} is itself a sentence, then
the [و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2}
is not used.

For example:

(@ex000120) [ذَ ٰلِكَ ٱلْكِتَابُ لَا رَيْبَ فِيهِ]{.ar}
    [[[سورة البقرة]{.ar} 2:2](https://quran.com/2/2) cited by [أوضح المسالك لابن هشام]{.ar} 2/289 and [حالات الربط بواو الحال الجبار فتحي زيدان]{.ar}]{.citex}  
    "This is the Book about which there is no doubt"  
    (The sentence [لَا رَيْبَ فِيهِ]{.ar}, in this interpretation, is analyzed as a [HAl]{.trn2} to the preceding sentence [ذَ ٰلِكَ ٱلْكِتَابُ]{.ar}.)

### The sentence [HAl]{.trn2} is a post-conjunction

If a sentence [HAl]{.trn2} is preceded by a conjunction (see section (multiple hals) above),
then an additional
[و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2}
is not typically tacked on to the conjunction.

For example:

(@ex000121) [فَجَاءَهَا بَأْسُنَا بَيَاتًا أَوْ هُمْ قَائِلُونَ]{.ar}
    [[[سورة الأعراف]{.ar} 7:4](https://quran.com/7/4)]{.citex}  
    "and Our punishment came to them at night or while they were sleeping at noon."  
    (An additional [و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2} is not tacked on to the conjunction [أَوْ]{.ar}.)

However, according to some grammarians, a
[و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2},
can be added to the conjunction and it would be acceptable.^[[حالات الربط بواو الحال الجبار فتحي زيدان]{.ar} citing [معاني القرآن للفراء]{.ar}]
For example:

(@ex000122) [أَتَيْتَنِى وَالِيًا أَوْ وَأَنَا مَعْزُولٌ]{.ar}
    [[[معاني القرآن للفراء]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/farraa/7/4) for [سورة الأعراف]{.ar} 7:4]{.citex}  
    "You came to me, while I was adjacent, or while I was remote."

## Purposes of the [و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2}

The
[و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2}
essentially distances the [HAl]{.trn2} from the influence of the governing verb.^[[دلائل الإعجاز للجرجاني]{.ar} 1/213--214 cited by [معاني النحو]{.ar} 357--358]
For example, consider the expression:

(@ex000123) [جَاءَنِي زَيْدٌ يُسْرِعُ]{.ar}
    [[دلائل الإعجاز للجرجاني]{.ar} 1/213]{.citex}  
    "Zayd came to me hastening."

The above example is almost equivalent to saying
[جَاءَنِي زَيْدٌ مُسْرِعًا]{.ar}.
The [HAl]{.trn2} [يُسْرِعُ]{.ar} is tightly bound to the governor [جَاءَ]{.ar}.
So the expression asserts Zayd's coming and his hastening as one assertion.
<!--
Zayd's hastening is contained within his action of coming.
-->

Consider now the expression with the [و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2}:

(@ex000124) [جَاءَنِي زَيْدٌ وَهُوَ يُسْرِعُ]{.ar}
    [[دلائل الإعجاز للجرجاني]{.ar} 1/214]{.citex}  
    "Zayd came to me while he was hastening."

Here the [HAl]{.trn2} sentence
[وَهُوَ يُسْرِعُ]{.ar}
is a more independent assertion.
Now, the only link between the [HAl]{.trn2} and its governing verb is
that the [HAl]{.trn2} expresses the state of the person of ḥāl when the action of the governing verb took place.

<!--This distancing effect of the [و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2} can be used for several purposes.-->
The [و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2} can be used for a different purposes.
We will list them below.
In the following discussion, there will be three distinct expressions that we will refer to:

  i. The [و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2}
 ii. The [HAl]{.trn2} sentence which follows the [و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2}
iii. The _preceding statement_ which precedes the [و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2}

Here are some purposes of the [و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2}:

* The [و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2} indicates that the event in the preceding statement took place at the time when the [HAl]{.trn2} occurred.
  For example:

  (@) [جَاءَ زَيْدٌ وٱلشَّمْسُ طَالِعَةٌ]{.ar}
      [[مغني اللبيب لابن هشام]{.ar} 606 cited by [معاني النحو]{.ar} 2/361]{.citex}  
      "Zayd came when the sun was risen."

  (@) [سَأَزُورُكَ وٱلْقَمَرُ طَالِعٌ]{.ar}
      [[معاني النحو]{.ar} 2/367]{.citex}  
      "I will visit you when the moon is risen."

* The [و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2} indicates that the person of ḥāl was already in the state described by the [HAl]{.trn2} before the event in the preceding statement occurred.
  For example:

  (@) [وَمَا لَنَا أَلَّا نُقَاتِلَ فِي سَبِيلِ ٱللَّهِ وَقَدْ أُخْرِجْنَا مِنْ دِيَارِنَا وَأَبْنَائِنَا]{.ar}
      [[[سورة البقرة]{.ar} 2:246](https://quran.com/2/246) cited by [معاني النحو]{.ar} 2/368]{.citex}  
      ""And why should we not fight in the cause of Allāh when we have been driven out from our homes and from our children?"


* The [و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2} indicates that the [HAl]{.trn2} after it is something obvious and should be taken into account, when considering the preceding statement.
  For example:

  (@) [أَمْ حَسِبْتُمْ أَنْ تَدْخُلُوا ٱلْجَنَّةَ وَلَمَّا يَأْتِكُمْ مَثَلُ ٱلَّذِينَ خَلَوْا مِنْ قَبْلِكُمْ]{.ar}
      [[[سورة البقرة]{.ar} 2:214](https://quran.com/2/214) cited by [معاني النحو]{.ar} 2/367]{.citex}  
      "Or do you think that you will enter Paradise while such [trial] has not yet come to you as came to those who passed on before you?"

  (@) [أَرَأَيْتَ لَوْ مَضْمَضْتَ مِنَ الْمَاءِ وَأَنْتَ صَائِمٌ]{.ar}
      [[[سنن أبي داود]{.ar} :2385](https://sunnah.com/abudawud:2385)]{.citex}  
      "What do you think if you rinse your mouth with water while you are fasting?"

* The [و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2} indicates that the [HAl]{.trn2} sentence is is describing something extraordinary.
  For example:

  (@) [عَبَرَ ٱلنَّهْرَ وَلَمْ يُحَرِّكْ يَدَهُ]{.ar}
      [[معاني النحو]{.ar} 2/368]{.citex}  
      "He crossed the river while not (even) moving his hand!"

  (@) [دَخَلَ عَلَى ٱلْأَمِيرِ وَبِيَدِهِ سَيْفُهُ]{.ar}
      [[معاني النحو]{.ar} 2/368]{.citex}  
      "He entered upon the commander while in his hand was his sword!"

* To differentiate between a [HAl]{.trn2} and a attribute.
  For example:

  (@) [رَأَيْتُ رَجُلًا عِنْدَهُ مَالٌ]{.ar}
      [[معاني النحو]{.ar} 2/368]{.citex}  
      "I saw a man (who) had wealth."  
      (The sentence [عِنْدَهُ مَالٌ]{.ar} can be analyzed as a attribute.)

  (@) [رَأَيْتُ رَجُلًا وَعِنْدَهُ مَالٌ]{.ar}
      [[معاني النحو]{.ar} 2/368]{.citex}  
      "I saw a man while he had wealth."  
      (The sentence [عِنْدَهُ مَالٌ]{.ar} can only be analyzed as a [HAl]{.trn2}.)

There may be other purposes as well.^[[معاني النحو]{.ar} 2/368--369]
      
## A quasi-sentence as the [HAl]{.trn2}

(Compare this section to section\ (ref).)
A quasi-sentence, in this context, is a prepositional or adverbial phrase.
For example: 
[عَلَى ٱلْغُصْنِ]{.ar}
"on the branch"
and
[بَيْنَ ٱلسَّحَابِ]{.ar}
"between the clouds".

Just like a complete sentence,
a quasi-sentence too may occur as a [HAl]{.trn2}.
For example:

(@haal-shibh-jumlah-crescent) [رَأَيْتُ ٱلْهِلَالَ بَيْنَ ٱلسَّحَابِ]{.ar}
    [[أوضح المسالك لابن هشام]{.ar} 2/285]{.citex}  
    "I saw the crescent between the clouds."  
    ([بَيْنَ ٱلسَّحَابِ]{.ar} is analyzed as a [HAl]{.trn2}.)

(@haal-shibh-jumlah-sparrow) [نَظَرْتُ ٱلْعُصْفُورَ عَلَى ٱلْغُصْنِ]{.ar}
    [[جامع الدروس العربية لمصطفى الغلاييني]{.ar} 3/101]{.citex}  
    "I looked at the sparrow on the branch."

(@haal-shibh-jumlah-wrote) [كتب عمر إلى أبي عبيدة بالشام]{.ar}
    [[الأصول في النحو لابن السراج]{.ar} 2/52]{.citex}  
    "[#eumar]{.trn2} wrote to [#abI #eubaydah]{.trn2} in Syria."

(@ex000125) [فَخَرَجَ عَلَىٰ قَوْمِهِ فِى زِينَتِهِ]{.ar}
    [[[سورة القصص]{.ar} 28:79](https://quran.com/28/79) cited by [أوضح المسالك لابن هشام]{.ar} 2/285]{.citex}  
    "So he came out before his people in his adornment."  
    ([فِى زِينَتِهِ]{.ar} is analyzed as a [HAl]{.trn2}.^[See [[تفسير ابن عاشور]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/ibn-aashoor/28/79) for [سورة القصص]{.ar} 28:79])

(@ex000126) [وَيُكَلِّمُ ٱلنَّاسَ فِي ٱلْمَهْدِ]{.ar}
    [[[سورة آل عمران]{.ar} 3:46](https://quran.com/3/46)]{.citex}  
    "He will speak to the people in the cradle"  
    ([فِي ٱلْمَهْدِ]{.ar} has been analyzed as a [HAl]{.trn2}.^[[[البحر المحيط لأبي حيان]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/albahr-almuheet/3/46) for [سورة آل عمران]{.ar} 3:46])


Now, you might be thinking: Didn't we learn
in chapter\ (ref) that [بَيْنَ]{.ar} is an adverb of place?
So why are we now saying that it is a [HAl]{.trn2}?

Well, first of all,
we are saying that the quasi-sentence
[بَيْنَ ٱلسَّحَابِ]{.ar}
is a [HAl]{.trn2}, not just 
[بَيْنَ]{.ar}.
Secondly, we say that the quasi-sentence is a [HAl]{.trn2} only loosely speaking.

Remember that an adverb of time or place is governed by a verb.
And the adverb of time or place indicates the time or place where the action of the verb occurred.
In a sentence like (@haal-shibh-jumlah-crescent) [رَأَيْتُ ٱلْهِلَالَ بَيْنَ ٱلسَّحَابِ]{.ar},
the crescent was between the clouds before the action of seeing took place.
So, in this case, we say that
[بَيْنَ]{.ar}
is an adverb of place, but it is governed,
not by the verb
[رَأَىٰ]{.ar},
but by an implied general beingness (see section\ (ref))
So it is as if we are saying:

"I saw the crescent (while it was) [being]^between\ the\ clouds^."

And it is this implied general beingness which is technically the [HAl]{.trn2}.^[[جامع الدروس العربية لمصطفى الغلاييني]{.ar} 3/101]
While
[بَيْنَ]{.ar}
remains (technically) an adverb of place.

Because the actual [HAl]{.trn2} "being" is (necessarily) unexpressed and only implied,
we can loosely say that the quasi-sentence
[بَيْنَ ٱلسَّحَابِ]{.ar}
is a [HAl]{.trn2}.

Similarly,
in example (@haal-shibh-jumlah-sparrow) [نَظَرْتُ ٱلْعُصْفُورَ عَلَى ٱلْغُصْنِ]{.ar},
the prepositional phrase
[عَلَى ٱلْغُصْنِ]{.ar}
is governed, not by the verb
[نَظَرَ]{.ar}
but by an implied verb "being" which is the true [HAl]{.trn2}.
But, loosely speaking, we may say that the quasi-sentence
[عَلَى ٱلْغُصْنِ]{.ar}
is the [HAl]{.trn2}.

Similarly,
in example (@haal-shibh-jumlah-wrote) [كتب عمر إلى أبي عبيدة بالشام]{.ar},
the act of writing was dony by [#eumar]{.trn2} in [al-#HijAz]{.trn2}, not in Syria.
So the prepositional phrase
[بالشام]{.ar}
is describing the state of
[#abU #eubaydah]{.trn2}
while he was in Syria.

This is yet another instance of where the lines between different types of adverbs get blurred.
In fact, some grammarians have classified the [HAl]{.trn2} to be of the same class of adverbs as the adverb of time and the adverb of place.^[[المقتضب للمبرد]{.ar} 4/166]



From the perspective of meaning,
the quasi-sentence
[بَيْنَ ٱلسَّحَابِ]{.ar}
"between the clouds"
describes the state of the person of ḥāl
[ٱلْهِلَالُ]{.ar}
during the occurrence of the verb [رَأَىٰ]{.ar}.
Similarly,
the quasi-sentence
[عَلَى ٱلْغُصْنِ]{.ar}
"on the branch"
describes the state of the person of ḥāl
[ٱلْعُصْفُور]{.ar}
during the occurrence of the verb [نَظَرَ]{.ar}.

<!--
So the quasi-sentence [HAl]{.trn2} must be uninfluenced, or pre-existing, before the action of any overt verb in the preceding statement.
-->

Here is an example of where the quasi-sentence does not work as a [HAl]{.trn2}:

(@ex000127) [وَقَعَ ٱلْحَجَرُ فِي ٱلْحُفْرَةِ]{.ar}  
    "The stone fell in the pit."

In the above example,
the stone went in the pit due to the action of the verb [وَقَعَ]{.ar}.
So the preposition [فِي]{.ar} is governed by the verb [وَقَعَ]{.ar}.
Because [فِي]{.ar} is not governed by an implied governor meaning "being",
therefore, the quasi-sentence
[فِي ٱلْحُفْرَةِ]{.ar}
is not a [HAl]{.trn2}.

One indicator to test if the quasi-sentence is valid as [HAl]{.trn2} in any particular sentence,
is to insert a [و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2} and a pronoun
(referring to the person of ḥāl)
before the quasi-sentence
(thus making it a complete sentence).
The purpose of the [و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2}, here, is to make the [HAl]{.trn2} a pre-existing state.
If the resulting expression
(with the [و]{.ar} of [HAl]{.trn2} is interpreted as making the [HAl]{.trn2} a pre-existing state)
retains the same meaning as the original, then
the quasi-sentence could be valid as a [HAl]{.trn2}.
Let's use this test on some of the examples above.

(@ex000128) [وَقَعَ ٱلْحَجَرُ وَهُوَ فِي ٱلْحُفْرَةِ]{.ar}  
    "The stone fell while it had already been in the pit."  
    (This does not retain the same meaning as the original [وَقَعَ ٱلْحَجَرُ فِي ٱلْحُفْرَةِ]{.ar}. So the quasi-sentence in the original example is not a [HAl]{.trn2}.)

(@ex000129) [رَأَيْتُ ٱلْهِلَالَ وَهُوَ بَيْنَ ٱلسَّحَابِ]{.ar}  
    "I saw the crescent while it had already been between the clouds."  
    (This retains the meaning of the original [رَأَيْتُ ٱلْهِلَالَ بَيْنَ ٱلسَّحَابِ]{.ar}. So the quasi-sentence in the original example is valid as a [HAl]{.trn2}.)

(@ex000130) [نَظَرْتُ ٱلْعُصْفُورَ وَهُوَ عَلَى ٱلْغُصْنِ]{.ar}  
    "I looked at the sparrow while it had already been on the branch."  
    (This retains the meaning of the original [نَظَرْتُ ٱلْعُصْفُورَ عَلَى ٱلْغُصْنِ]{.ar}. So the quasi-sentence in the original example is valid as a [HAl]{.trn2}.)

There may be examples where a quasi-sentence could be validly interpreted either as a [HAl]{.trn2} 
(governed by an implied governor meaning "being"),
or as governed by an overt verb.^[See also, for example, the [tafsIr]{.trn2} of [تَحْتَ ٱلشَّجَرَةِ]{.ar} in [[البحر المحيط لأبي حيان]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/albahr-almuheet/48/18) for [سورة الفتح]{.ar} 48:18]
For example:

(@ex000131) [رأيتُ زيدًا في الدار]{.ar}
    [[الأصول في النحو لابن السراج]{.ar} 2/52]{.citex}  
    "I saw Zayd in the house."

Without context, the prepositional phrase
[في الدار]{.ar}
could either be governed by [رَأَىٰ]{.ar}, signifying that the act of seeing was done in the house.
Or it could be governed by the implication of general beingness, as a [HAl]{.trn2} for [زَيْد]{.ar}.^[[الأصول في النحو لابن السراج]{.ar} 2/52]

A quasi-sentence can only be a [HAl]{.trn2} if it is governed by an implied (unexpressed) governor.
This implicated governor will typically be general beingness, as in the examples above.^[[أوضح المسالك لابن هشام]{.ar} 2/285, [شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/213]
In fact, some grammarians insist that the implied governor can only be general beingness.^[[[البحر المحيط لأبي حيان]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/albahr-almuheet/3/194) for [سورة آل عمران]{.ar} 3:194 ([مَا وَعَدْتَنَا عَلَىٰ رُسُلِكَ]{.ar})]
However, it is conceivable that the implied governor of the preposition be interpreted, if not formally then at least in meaning, as some other verb (or verbal noun).^[[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 2/447 footnote]
For example:

(@ex000132) [رَبَّنَا وَءَاتِنَا مَا وَعَدتَّنَا عَلَىٰ رُسُلِكَ]{.ar}
    [[[سورة آل عمران]{.ar} 3:194](https://quran.com/3/194)]{.citex}  
    "Our Lord, and grant us what You promised us through Your messengers"

In one interpretation of the above [Ayah]{.trn2},
the 
prepositional phrase
[عَلَىٰ رُسُلِكَ]{.ar}
"through Your messengers"
has been analyzed as [HAl]{.trn2} of
[مَا وَعَدتَّنَا]{.ar}
"what You promised us"
The meaning with the implicated governor has been explained as
[مُنَزَّلًا عَلَيْهِمْ]{.ar}
"_sent down_ on [Your messengers]."^[[[تفسير ابن عاشور]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/ibn-aashoor/3/194) for [سورة آل عمران]{.ar} 3:194]

## Interpreting a sentence as a [HAl]{.trn2} vs. a attribute

We have just seen how a sentence
(or quasi-sentence)
can be intrepreted as a [HAl]{.trn2}.
And we already know that a sentence
(or quasi-sentence)
can be intrepreted as a attribute.
So how can we tell when
a sentence
(or quasi-sentence)
is a [HAl]{.trn2} vs. when it is a attribute?

We may use the following guidelines^[[مغني اللبيب لابن هشام]{.ar} 560]:

* When
  a sentence
  (or quasi-sentence)
  occurs after a specific definite noun,
  then it will be a [HAl]{.trn2}.

* And when
  a sentence
  (or quasi-sentence)
  occurs after a unspecified indefinite noun,
  then it will be a attribute.

* And when 
  a sentence
  (or quasi-sentence)
  occurs after a generic definite noun
  or an specified indefinite noun
  then it may be interpreted as either a [HAl]{.trn2} or a attribute.

  However, in this case when both the attribute and the [HAl]{.trn2} interpretations are possible,
  one may still be preferred over the other 
  depending on what the overall meaning and context demands.^[[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 3/477]

  This is because
  when a sentence is interpreted as a [HAl]{.trn2} then it will be describing the state of the person of ḥāl.
  And when a sentence is interpreted as a attribute then it will be specifying or identifying the attributee.

What we mean by a _specific definite_ noun is one that refers to a specific entity.
Not one that refers to a generic type
(for which Arabic also uses the definite).

For example,
in the sentence
[زَيْدٌ فِي ٱلدَّارِ]{.ar} "Zayd is in the house,"
[زَيْدٌ]{.ar} is a specific definite noun
because it refers to a specific person.
On the other hand,
if we say
[ٱلْفِيلُ حَيَوانٌ]{.ar} "The elephant is an animal,"
then we may be using
[ٱلْفِيل]{.ar}
to refer to the species,
and not a specific elephant.
In this case,
[ٱلْفِيل]{.ar}
is a _generic definite_ noun.

And what we mean by an unspecified indefinite noun is one that is not restricted by a attribute or other qualifier.
So it is applicable to any entity denoted by that noun.
For example, [رَجُل]{.ar} in
[فِي ٱلدَّارِ رَجُلٌ]{.ar}
is an unspecified indefinite noun.
But in 
[فِي ٱلدَّارِ رَجُلٌ كَبِيرٌ]{.ar}
and
[فِي ٱلدَّارِ رَجُلُ خَيْرٍ]{.ar}
it is a specified indefinite noun.

Here are some examples of sentences analyzed as attributes or [HAl]{.trn2}s:

(@ex000133) [حَتَّىٰ تُنَزِّلَ عَلَيْنَا كِتَابًا نَقْرَؤُهُ]{.ar}
    [[[سورة الإسراء]{.ar} 17:93](https://quran.com/17/93) cited by [مغني اللبيب لابن هشام]{.ar} 560]{.citex}  
    "until you bring down to us a book we may read"  
    ([نَقُرَؤُهُ]{.ar} is analyzed as a attribute because [كِتَاب]{.ar} is an unspecified indefinite noun.)

(@ex000134) [فَلَقَدْ رَأَيْتُهُ يَقِيهَا مِنَ الْحِجَارَةِ بِنَفْسِهِ]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح مسلم]{.ar} :1699a](https://sunnah.com/muslim:1699a)]{.citex}  
    "for indeed I saw him protecting her from the stones with his [body]."  
    ([يَقِيهَا]{.ar} is analyzed as a [HAl]{.trn2} because the pronoun [ه]{.ar} in [رَأَيْتُهُ]{.ar} is a specific definite noun.)

(@ex000135) [وَقَالُوا لَوْلَا نُزِّلَ هَـٰذَا ٱلْقُرْءَانُ عَلَىٰ رَجُلٍ مِنَ ٱلْقَرْيَتَيْنِ عَظِيمٍ]{.ar}
    [[[سورة الزخرف]{.ar} 43:31](https://quran.com/43/31)]{.citex}  
    And they said, "Why was this Qur’ān not sent down upon a great man from [one of] the two cities?"  
    ([مِنَ ٱلْقَرْيَتَيْنِ]{.ar} is a attribute to [رَجُل]{.ar}. [عَظِيم]{.ar} is a second attribute.)

(@ex000136) [كَمَثَلِ ٱلْحِمَارِ يَحْمِلُ أَسْفَارًا]{.ar}
    [[[سورة الجمعة]{.ar} 62:5](https://quran.com/62/5) cited by [مغني اللبيب لابن هشام]{.ar} 561]{.citex}  
    "is like that of a donkey who carries volumes [of books]"  
    ([ٱلْحِمَارِ]{.ar} is a generic definite noun. So, the sentence [يَحْمِلُ أَسْفَارًا]{.ar} has been analyzed as either a [HAl]{.trn2} or a attribute.^[[[الكشاف للزمخشري]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/kashaf/62/5) for [سورة الجمعة]{.ar} 62:5])

Consider now the following example:

(@ex000137) [وَقَالَ رَجُلٌ مُؤْمِنٌ مِنْ آلِ فِرْعَوْنَ يَكْتُمُ إِيمَانَهُ]{.ar}
    [[[سورة غافر]{.ar} 40:28](https://quran.com/40/28)]{.citex}  
    "And a believing man from the family of Pharaoh who concealed his faith said,"

In the above example, there are two (quasi-) sentences after the first attribute [مُؤْمِن]{.ar}:

 i. [مِنْ آلِ فِرْعَوْنَ]{.ar}
ii. [يَكْتُمُ إِيمَانَهُ]{.ar}

There are now multiple possible interpretations:

Since [رَجُلٌ]{.ar} is now a specified indefinite noun
(having been described by the attribute [مُؤْمِنٌ]{.ar})
it is permissible for both
[مِنْ آلِ فِرْعَوْنَ]{.ar}
and
[يَكْتُمُ إِيمَانَهُ]{.ar}
to be [HAl]{.trn2}s.
Or 
[مِنْ آلِ فِرْعَوْنَ]{.ar}
can be a attribute
and
[يَكْتُمُ إِيمَانَهُ]{.ar}
can be a [HAl]{.trn2}.
Or both
[مِنْ آلِ فِرْعَوْنَ]{.ar}
and
[يَكْتُمُ إِيمَانَهُ]{.ar}
can be attributes.^[[[تفسير ابن عثيمين]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/ibn-uthaymeen/40/28) for [سورة غافر]{.ar} 40:28]

## Multiple [HAl]{.trn2}s when one or more is a sentence or quasi-sentence

From section\ (ref) earlier in this chapter,
we learned that there may be more than one [HAl]{.trn2} for one person of ḥāl.
These multiple [HAl]{.trn2}s may consist of sentence and quasi-sentence [HAl]{.trn2}s.
For example:

(@ex000138) [فَنَادَتْهُ ٱلْمَلَائِكَةُ وَهُوَ قَائِمٌ يُصَلِّی فِی ٱلْمِحْرَابِ]{.ar}
    [[[سورة آل عمران]{.ar} 3:39](https://quran.com/3/39)]{.citex}  
    "So the angels called him while he was standing in prayer in the chamber,"  
    ([هُوَ قَائِمٌ]{.ar} and  [يُصَلِّی فِی ٱلْمِحْرَابِ]{.ar} have both been analyzed as [HAl]{.trn2}s as one interpretation.^[[[البحر المحيط لأبي حيان]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/albahr-almuheet/3/39) for [سورة آل عمران]{.ar} 3:39])

When one or more of these multiple [HAl]{.trn2}s is a sentence
or quasi-sentence,
then it is usual,
though not imperative,
that the [HAl]{.trn2}s be in the following order^[[[البحر المحيط لأبي حيان]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/albahr-almuheet/3/46) for [سورة آل عمران]{.ar} 3:46]:

1. First, any [HAl]{.trn2}s that are comprised of a single word
2. Then any quasi-sentence [HAl]{.trn2}s
3. Then any sentence [HAl]{.trn2}s

This is the same order that is usually followed for attributes as well.

Here is an example:

(@ex000139) [فَخَرَجَ مِنْهَا خَائِفًا يَتَرَقَّبُ]{.ar}
    [[[سورة القصص]{.ar} 28:21](https://quran.com/28/21)]{.citex}  
    "So he left it, fearful and anticipating [apprehension]."

## Suppressing the governor of the [HAl]{.trn2}

The 
governor of the [HAl]{.trn2}
may be suppressed
(i.e. omitted)
in some cases optionally,
and in other cases necessarily.
We will discuss these cases below

### Optional suppressing of the governor of the [HAl]{.trn2}

### Necessary suppressing of the governor of the [HAl]{.trn2}

The governor is also omitted when it is conceptual with the meaning "existing" or "being".
We have seen this in section\ (ref) above.
